data.title: IP address translation
data.solution:
n = int(input())
for i in range(n):
    addr = [*map(int, input().split('.'))]
    if len(addr) == 2:
        # Class A address.
        # If you've ever wondered why "1.1" can be resolved
        # by some tools to "1.0.0.1"... ;-)
        addr = addr[:1] + [
            (addr[1] >> 16) & 255, 
            (addr[1] >> 8) & 255, 
            addr[1] & 255
        ]
    elif len(addr) == 3:
        # Class B address.
        addr = addr[:2] + [
            (addr[2] >> 8) & 255, 
            addr[2] & 255
        ]
    
    print(''.join(map(chr, addr)).lower() + '.com')
data.statement:
The French administration is notoriously bad at technology. On one of the French institutional websites, it is written that <<a domain name is the literal translation of an IP address>>. This puzzle is based on that assumption.

You must determine the domain names associated with the provided IPv4 addresses.

An IPv4 address can be provided in any of these forms:

* {{A.B.C.D}}: basic format, e.g. {{97.98.99.100}}.
* {{A.B.C}}: historical format for class B addresses, e.g. {{97.98.25444}}.
* {{A.B}}: historical format for class A addresses, e.g. {{97.6447972}}.

Note that:

* In the {{A.B.C}} format, {{C}} is a 16-bit number with the higher 8 bits being {{C}} and the lower 8 bits being {{D}} from the basic format.
* In the {{A.B}} format, {{B}} is a 24-bit number with the higher 8 bits being {{B}}, the middle 8 bits being {{C}}, and the lower 8 bits being {{D}} from the basic format.

Every byte is set to the ASCII code of the character to set at the corresponding index, and the {{.com}} top-level domain must be used.

Note that the resulting domain must be lowercased, since domain names are case insensitive. (don't worry about bijection)

Some examples are the following:

* {{97.98.99.100}}, {{97.98.26992}} and {{97.6447972}} are translated into {{abcd.com}}.
* {{97.45.104.97}}, {{97.45.26721}} and {{97.2975841}} are translated into {{a-ha.com}}.
* {{65.66.67.68}}, {{65.66.17220}} and {{65.4342596}} are translated into {{abcd.com}} ({{ABCD.com}} lowercased).

All of the provided IPv4 addresses translate to valid domains.

lastVersion.statementHTML:
Goal

The French administration is notoriously bad at technology. On one of the French institutional websites, it is written that a domain name is the literal translation of an IP address. This puzzle is based on that assumption.

You must determine the domain names associated with the provided IPv4 addresses.

An IPv4 address can be provided in any of these forms:

* A.B.C.D: basic format, e.g. 97.98.99.100.
* A.B.C: historical format for class B addresses, e.g. 97.98.25444.
* A.B: historical format for class A addresses, e.g. 97.6447972.

Note that:

* In the A.B.C format, C is a 16-bit number with the higher 8 bits being C and the lower 8 bits being D from the basic format.
* In the A.B format, B is a 24-bit number with the higher 8 bits being B, the middle 8 bits being C, and the lower 8 bits being D from the basic format.

Every byte is set to the ASCII code of the character to set at the corresponding index, and the .com top-level domain must be used.

Note that the resulting domain must be lowercased, since domain names are case insensitive. (don't worry about bijection)

Some examples are the following:

* 97.98.99.100, 97.98.26992 and 97.6447972 are translated into abcd.com.
* 97.45.104.97, 97.45.26721 and 97.2975841 are translated into a-ha.com.
* 65.66.67.68, 65.66.17220 and 65.4342596 are translated into abcd.com (ABCD.com lowercased).

All of the provided IPv4 addresses translate to valid domains.
Input
First line: An integer n being the number of IPv4 addresses to translate.
Next n lines: One IPv4 address per line, in basic, class A or class B format.
Output
n lines: Domain of the corresponding address.
Constraints
1 <= n < 16
1 <= ip address length <= 20
Example
Input
2
97.98.99.100
97.45.104.97
Output
abcd.com
a-ha.com
